entries.title: Softchoice Website Rebrand
entries.tag: Brand Design, Motion Design, CMS Integration
entries.subtitle: Polishing a Brand Identity in Motion
entries.description: When a brand launches a new identity, the website needs to reflect it—without breaking what already works. Redesigned Softchoice's website to reflect their new brand identity, working within their existing CMS structure. Enhanced modules, introduced motion design, and collaborated closely with development to ensure design fidelity.
entries.label: Read Case Study

keypoints.title: Consistent Brand Identity
keypoints.body: The website now fully reflects Softchoice's new brand identity. Every module, every page, every interaction feels like it belongs to the same visual language. This consistency builds trust and reinforces brand recognition.

keypoints.title: Enhanced User Experience
keypoints.body: The thoughtful module redesign and light animations created a more engaging and intuitive interface. Users don't notice the individual improvements—they just feel that the site is more polished, more professional, more aligned with what they expect from Softchoice.

keypoints.title: Efficient Development Process
keypoints.body: Clear specifications and ongoing collaboration meant the development team could implement the design accurately without constant back-and-forth. The detailed guidelines reduced ambiguity and sped up the implementation phase.

keypoints.title: Collaborative Success
keypoints.body: This project required coordination between multiple parties: the design partner, the branding agency that created the new identity, and Softchoice's internal IT team. The success came from everyone understanding their role and working together toward a shared vision.

entries.title: The Challenge
entries.body:
In late 2020, Softchoice was preparing to launch a new brand identity in January. Their website, built on an interim design from August 2020, had incomplete design elements and wasn't ready to represent the new brand. The challenge wasn't just visual—it was about enhancing the experience while respecting the existing CMS architecture that was already serving the organization well.

The constraint: We couldn't rebuild the site. We had to work within the established module-driven CMS structure, enhancing and polishing without disrupting what was already functioning.

This is a common scenario in enterprise work: you're not starting from scratch. You're improving what exists while respecting the systems already in place.

images.caption: The existing website needed to reflect the new brand without breaking what already worked.

entries.title: The Approach
entries.body:
Rather than tearing down and rebuilding, we took a surgical approach: redesign the modules, not the system.

Brand Guidelines as the Foundation
The new brand guidelines were comprehensive—colors, typography, spacing, imagery principles. Our first step was to understand how these guidelines could translate into the existing module structure.

Module Redesign Strategy
The CMS was built on a block model approach. Key modules included hero sections, page navigation, two-column layouts, callouts and stats, image quadrants, text quadrants, related content sections, and accordions. Each module needed to be redesigned to reflect the new brand while maintaining its functional purpose.

Motion Design: Bringing Life to the Interface
One of the most impactful additions was introducing light animations and motion design. This wasn't about flashy effects—it was about enhancing the user experience through thoughtful motion: navigation behavior with smooth transitions, module loading that feels intentional, text appearance on scroll, and interactive navigation buttons with responsive feedback.

images.caption: Brand guidelines translated into module-driven design system.

entries.title: The Outcome
entries.body:
The rebrand wasn't just about new colors and fonts. It was about creating a cohesive experience that reflected Softchoice's new brand identity across every touchpoint.

Working within constraints—whether they're technical, timeline, or budget-related—forces you to be more creative, not less. We couldn't rebuild everything, so we had to be strategic about what to enhance and how to enhance it.

Sometimes the best design work happens when you're improving what exists rather than starting from scratch. It requires a different kind of creativity—one that sees potential in constraints and finds elegant solutions within established systems. This rebranding effort modernized Softchoice's online presence while respecting the foundation that was already working.

images.caption: Thoughtful motion design enhances the user experience without calling attention to itself.

entries.title: K&G Loyalty Platform
entries.description: Founded in 1959, Kum & Go redefines convenience with customer-centric offerings. Partnering with Orium, they launched a new digital experience featuring enhanced promotions, loyalty programs, and improved merchandising.
entries.label: Read More
entries.alt: K&G Loyalty Platform - Mobile App Experience

images.caption1: K&G Loyalty Platform - Mobile App Hero

keypoints.title: Control Over Digital Experience
keypoints.body: Empowering Kum & Go to manage their search, merchandising, promotions, loyalty, and content independently.

keypoints.title: Increased Customer Engagement
keypoints.body: Launching a robust loyalty program to engage a smallr segment of the consumer base.

keypoints.title: More In-Store Purchases
keypoints.body: Enhancing the omnichannel experience to drive more in-store purchases.

keypoints.title: Extensible and Maintainable Platform
keypoints.body: Moving off a costly legacy platform to a more efficient and innovative system.

entries.title: Problem
entries.body: Kum & Go aimed to redefine convenience for their customers by upgrading their digital experience. They sought to enhance their mobile app to include better search and merchandising, a new loyalty program, and support for modern shopping preferences. Additionally, the new app needed to be adaptable for future updates and improvements without causing any service disruptions.

images.caption: Identifying opportunities to enhance the mobile app experience.

entries.title: Solution
entries.body: To achieve these goals, Kum & Go partnered with Orium to implement a flexible and scalable platform focusing on four key objectives: control over digital experience, increased customer engagement, more in-store purchases, and an extensible platform. Orium worked with Kum & Go to develop a React Native framework, leveraging Orium's React Native Accelerator for a faster, more efficient development process. Contentful's composable content platform was implemented for easy content management, and Typesense was used for search and product indexing. Paytronix was chosen to manage the loyalty program, providing comprehensive loyalty, promotions, and ordering capabilities. Integration with P97 enhanced Mobile Fuel Pay, allowing for prepaying gas and redeeming points at the pump.

images.alt: React Native Framework and Composable Architecture
images.caption: Modern mobile architecture with React Native and composable content management.

entries.title: Outcome
entries.body:
The revamped Kum & Go mobile app launched with an upgraded rewards program and an enhanced ecommerce experience. Key features included a personalized interface, home location selection, and customer history-based recommendations. The Mobile Fuel Pay feature was also improved, allowing customers to prepay for gas in selected increments.

Kum & Go plans to continue enhancing the mobile app and redesigning the web experience to match the new mobile app features.

images.alt: K&G Mobile App Launch and Features
images.caption: Launched mobile app with enhanced loyalty program and ecommerce capabilities.

entries.description: Empowering technical users with precision, flexibility, and control for configuring industrial PC systems.
entries.label: Read More

keypoints.title: Empower Technical Users
keypoints.body: Designed an interface for IT professionals and developers, providing advanced customization options with usability in mind.

keypoints.title: Facilitate Developer Implementation
keypoints.body: Created UI workflows developers could implement and extend, aligning with composable architecture principles.

keypoints.title: Support High Customizability
keypoints.body: Enabled configuration and purchase of highly customizable products with seamless integration of pricing, tax rules, and global payment systems.

keypoints.title: Provide Transparency and Control
keypoints.body: Delivered detailed product configuration workflows with real-time feedback and clear user-facing data.

entries.title: Problem
entries.body: OnLogic needed a platform tailored to technical users, including IT professionals, to handle the complexities of configuring customizable products. The existing legacy platform couldn't provide the precision, transparency, or scalability required to meet the needs of a global audience.

images.caption: Legacy platform lacked configurability and scalability.

entries.title: Solution
entries.body: Migrated to a composable commerce architecture using commercetools, enabling OnLogic to scale and meet modern demands. Developed configurable PDPs with real-time price calculations, validation checks, and modular designs. Integrated content management (Contentful), search (Algolia), and custom payment/tax systems to meet global requirements.

images.caption: Composable architecture tailored for technical users.

entries.title: Outcome
entries.body: The platform empowered OnLogic's technical users with advanced customization options, seamless workflows, and real-time validation. Developers benefited from detailed design handoffs and modular implementation strategies. The scalable platform allows OnLogic to evolve its offerings to meet future needs.
